channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Assessing Fukushima Damage Without Eyes on the Inside
item.description: A new technology will give engineers three-dimensional images of the stricken plant’s reactor cores and detect damaged fuel behind feet of steel and concrete.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW L. WALD
item.media:credit: Hiroto Sekiguchi/Yomiuri Shimbun, via Associated Press
item.media:description: More than three years after the accident at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear complex, engineers have not examined many of the most important parts of the wreckage.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Don’t Fight in Iraq and Ignore Syria
item.description: Obama’s thinking on ISIS is confused and will lead to more problems.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ANNE-MARIE SLAUGHTER

item.title: As Chinese Leader Takes On Graft, Relatives Are Said to Shed Investments
item.description: Evidence suggests that President Xi Jinping has been pushing his kin to sell hundreds of millions of dollars in holdings, reducing his own political vulnerability.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China in Shanghai last month. Mr. Xi's family members have divested a significant portion of their fortunes, which may put him on a stronger footing as he oversees an anticorruption drive.

item.title: Ukraine Suspects Terrorism in Pipeline Explosion
item.description: Ukrainian officials suspect that terrorists blew up a natural gas pipeline a day after the Russian energy giant Gazprom said it was cutting off supplies to Ukraine in a dispute over pricing.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Ministry of Emergencies, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: The aftermath of an explosion at a natural gas pipeline in central Ukraine, in a photograph released by the Ukrainian Ministry Of Emergencies.

item.title: At War Blog: Torn Between Competing Perspectives on Iraq
item.description: The collapse of Iraq reveals some ugly truths about the real emotional stakes the United States had in the wars there and in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN CASTNER

item.title: U.S. Captures Top Suspect in Benghazi Siege, Pentagon Says
item.description: In a secret operation, American Special Operations forces captured Ahmed Abu Khattala, the suspected leader of the 2012 attack on the U.S. diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, and took him out of that country.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: The United States mission in Benghazi, Libya, was attacked on Sept. 11, 2012.

item.title: News: Israelis Start #BringBackOurBoys Campaign
item.description: Israelis trained to promote their country’s image online started a campaign last week, using a hashtag inspired by Nigerian activists, after three teenagers disappeared on their way home from religious schools in the occupied West Bank.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: 7 Killed as Pakistan Police Clash With Preacher’s Followers
item.description: The deaths occurred after officers demanded the removal of blockades from roads leading to the headquarters of the preacher, Muhammad Tahir-ul-Qadri.
item.dc:creator: By WAQAR GILLANI

item.title: Apprehension of Ahmed Abu Khattala May Begin to Answer Questions on Assault
item.description: The apprehension of Ahmed Abu Khattala may finally begin to address some of the persistent questions about who carried out the Libya attack and why.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Kenyan Leader Blames Domestic Foes, Not Shabab, for Attacks
item.description: President Uhuru Kenyatta said the killing of at least 57 people in two raids was the work of local “political networks,” not Islamic militants.
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Kenyan police officers walked past a bonfire used to barricade a main road in Mpeketoni, Kenya, on Tuesday. Militants killed at least 15 people on Kenya’s coast overnight.

item.title: Roma Boy, 16, Is Comatose After Beating Outside Paris
item.description: A 16-year-old Roma boy was abducted from a shantytown and beaten last week by as many as a dozen people in an attack that drew condemnation from politicians and rights groups.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE and MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: DealBook: Argentina’s Debt Appeal Is Rejected by Supreme Court
item.description: The Supreme Court handed Argentina two major defeats on Monday in cases brought by bondholders who refused to accept reduced payments after the country’s 2001 default.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM LIPTAK
item.media:description: Stockbrokers at the Buenos Aires Stock Exchange on Monday. The Supreme Court decision could upset Argentina’s bond market.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: June 17
item.description: A boy at Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh, at the confluence of the Ganges River and Yamuna River fishing out coins offered by Hindu devotees using magnets.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A boy removing coins, offered by Hindu devotees to the river, which were fished out using magnets at Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Keeps a Close Eye on Oil Interests in Iraq
item.description: As militants threaten to drag Iraq back into civil war, China National Petroleum Corporation, the largest state-owned energy company, anxiously monitors its substantial investments in the country.
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG and EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A refinery in Zubair, Iraq. China's largest state-owned energy company says it has invested billions in the Iraq oil industry.

item.title: India Ink: Central Bank Chief Resists Call to Expand Judicial Oversight
item.description: The governor of the Reserve Bank of India, Raghuram Rajan, expressed concern about a call for greater judicial oversight of bodies that regulate the financial industry.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: China Sends Top Diplomat To Begin Talks With Vietnam
item.description: A senior Chinese official will meet with Vietnam’s deputy prime minister in the first high-level discussions since tensions between the countries escalated in May.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Letter From Paris: Ode to the Classic Bistro
item.description: The definitive French spot that celebrates honest food and wine, a cozy atmosphere and great conversation is alive and well.
item.dc:creator: By ELAINE SCIOLINO
item.media:credit: Ed Alcock for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pair of extra-large organic hard-boiled eggs served with homemade mayonnaise from Bistrot Valois.

item.title: Global Health: A Faster Way to Find the Origin of Malaria
item.description: A DNA “bar code” of 23 snips from the genes of parasites that cause malaria can help scientists quickly determine where they originated, British researchers report.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Letter From India: Narendra Modi’s Election Sparks Hope for Sanskrit
item.description: Proponents of teaching the ancient scholarly language dream of its revival under the government of India’s new prime minister.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi, left, enters Parliament in New Delhi last week.

item.title: Open Source: As Brazil Cheers, Protesters Struggle to Be Heard
item.description: With Brazilians loudly rallying behind their national team in the World Cup, activists concerned about social issues have struggled to make their voices heard.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: City Aims to Play Down Its Dog Meat Festival
item.description: The feasting is expected to go ahead as scheduled in the southern city of Yulin, but officials have taken steps to deflect outside attention from the annual event, at which thousands of dogs are consumed.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Dog meat on sale ahead of the dog-eating festival in Yulin. Animal welfare advocates have called for an end to the event.

item.title: 44 Sunni Prisoners Killed as Iraqi Violence Spreads
item.description: The fighting moved closer to Baghdad, where the bodies of four young Sunni men were found in a Shiite neighborhood.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and SUADAD AL-SALHY
item.media:description: Members of Kurdish security forces detained a man near Kirkuk who was suspected of being a militant from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: U.S. Professors Call on Colleges to Re-evaluate Confucius Institutes
item.description: In an effort to uphold academic freedom, the American Association of University Professors asks colleges to terminate or renegotiate their agreements with Confucius Institutes, on-campus cultural and language programs backed by the Chinese government.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:credit: John Sleezer/Associated Press, via The Kansas City Star
item.media:description: Wu Qidi, Chinese deputy minister of education, spoke at the opening of the Confucius Institute at the University of Kansas' Edwards campus in 2006 with Kathleen Sebelius, then governor of Kansas, in the background.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Why Are Rwandans Disappearing?
item.description: A disturbing report suggests that the government is targeting its own people.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By LARA SANTORO and SUSAN THOMSON

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: China's Clampdown on 'Evil Cults'
item.description: Christianity's growing appeal is a mystery to many Chinese, and anathema to Beijing.
item.dc:creator: By MURONG XUECUN
